docs.text_entry: ACT I
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Enter KING HENRY, LORD JOHN OF LANCASTER, the EARL of WESTMORELAND, SIR WALTER BLUNT, and others

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: So shaken as we are, so wan with care,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Find we a time for frighted peace to pant,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And breathe short-winded accents of new broils

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: To be commenced in strands afar remote.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: No more the thirsty entrance of this soil

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Shall daub her lips with her own childrens blood;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Nor more shall trenching war channel her fields,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Nor bruise her flowerets with the armed hoofs

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Of hostile paces: those opposed eyes,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Which, like the meteors of a troubled heaven,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: All of one nature, of one substance bred,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Did lately meet in the intestine shock

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And furious close of civil butchery

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Shall now, in mutual well-beseeming ranks,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: March all one way and be no more opposed

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Against acquaintance, kindred and allies:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: The edge of war, like an ill-sheathed knife,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: No more shall cut his master. Therefore, friends,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: As far as to the sepulchre of Christ,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Whose soldier now, under whose blessed cross

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: We are impressed and engaged to fight,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Forthwith a power of English shall we levy;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Whose arms were moulded in their mothers womb

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: To chase these pagans in those holy fields

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Over whose acres walkd those blessed feet

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Which fourteen hundred years ago were naild

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: For our advantage on the bitter cross.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: But this our purpose now is twelve month old,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And bootless tis to tell you we will go:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Therefore we meet not now. Then let me hear

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Of you, my gentle cousin Westmoreland,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: What yesternight our council did decree

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: In forwarding this dear expedience.

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: My liege, this haste was hot in question,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: And many limits of the charge set down

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: But yesternight: when all athwart there came

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: A post from Wales loaden with heavy news;

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Whose worst was, that the noble Mortimer,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Against the irregular and wild Glendower,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Was by the rude hands of that Welshman taken,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: A thousand of his people butchered;

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Upon whose dead corpse there was such misuse,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Such beastly shameless transformation,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: By those Welshwomen done as may not be

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Without much shame retold or spoken of.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: It seems then that the tidings of this broil

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Brake off our business for the Holy Land.

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: This matchd with other did, my gracious lord;

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: For more uneven and unwelcome news

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Came from the north and thus it did import:

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: On Holy-rood day, the gallant Hotspur there,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Young Harry Percy and brave Archibald,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: That ever-valiant and approved Scot,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: At Holmedon met,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Where they did spend a sad and bloody hour,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: As by discharge of their artillery,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: And shape of likelihood, the news was told;

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: For he that brought them, in the very heat

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: And pride of their contention did take horse,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Uncertain of the issue any way.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Here is a dear, a true industrious friend,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Sir Walter Blunt, new lighted from his horse.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Staind with the variation of each soil

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Betwixt that Holmedon and this seat of ours;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And he hath brought us smooth and welcome news.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: The Earl of Douglas is discomfited:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Ten thousand bold Scots, two and twenty knights,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Balkd in their own blood did Sir Walter see

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: On Holmedons plains. Of prisoners, Hotspur took

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Mordake the Earl of Fife, and eldest son

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: To beaten Douglas; and the Earl of Athol,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Of Murray, Angus, and Menteith:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And is not this an honourable spoil?

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: A gallant prize? ha, cousin, is it not?

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: In faith,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: It is a conquest for a prince to boast of.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Yea, there thou makest me sad and makest me sin

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: In envy that my Lord Northumberland

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Should be the father to so blest a son,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: A son who is the theme of honours tongue;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Amongst a grove, the very straightest plant;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Who is sweet Fortunes minion and her pride:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Whilst I, by looking on the praise of him,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: See riot and dishonour stain the brow

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Of my young Harry. O that it could be proved

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: That some night-tripping fairy had exchanged

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: In cradle-clothes our children where they lay,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And calld mine Percy, his Plantagenet!

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Then would I have his Harry, and he mine.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: But let him from my thoughts. What think you, coz,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Of this young Percys pride? the prisoners,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Which he in this adventure hath surprised,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: To his own use he keeps; and sends me word,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: I shall have none but Mordake Earl of Fife.

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: This is his uncles teaching; this is Worcester,

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Malevolent to you in all aspects;

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Which makes him prune himself, and bristle up

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: The crest of youth against your dignity.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: But I have sent for him to answer this;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And for this cause awhile we must neglect

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Our holy purpose to Jerusalem.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Cousin, on Wednesday next our council we

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Will hold at Windsor; so inform the lords:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: But come yourself with speed to us again;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: For more is to be said and to be done

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Than out of anger can be uttered.

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: I will, my liege.

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Exeunt

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: SCENE II. London. An apartment of the Princes.

docs.speaker: WESTMORELAND
docs.text_entry: Enter the PRINCE OF WALES and FALSTAFF

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Now, Hal, what time of day is it, lad?

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Thou art so fat-witted, with drinking of old sack

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: and unbuttoning thee after supper and sleeping upon

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: benches after noon, that thou hast forgotten to

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: demand that truly which thou wouldst truly know.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: What a devil hast thou to do with the time of the

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: day? Unless hours were cups of sack and minutes

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: capons and clocks the tongues of bawds and dials the

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: signs of leaping-houses and the blessed sun himself

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: a fair hot wench in flame-coloured taffeta, I see no

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: reason why thou shouldst be so superfluous to demand

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: the time of the day.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Indeed, you come near me now, Hal; for we that take

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: purses go by the moon and the seven stars, and not

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: by Phoebus, he,that wandering knight so fair. And,

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: I prithee, sweet wag, when thou art king, as, God

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: save thy grace,--majesty I should say, for grace

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: thou wilt have none,--

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: What, none?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: No, by my troth, not so much as will serve to

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: prologue to an egg and butter.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Well, how then? come, roundly, roundly.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Marry, then, sweet wag, when thou art king, let not

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: us that are squires of the nights body be called

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: thieves of the days beauty: let us be Dianas

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: foresters, gentlemen of the shade, minions of the

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: moon; and let men say we be men of good government,

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: being governed, as the sea is, by our noble and

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: chaste mistress the moon, under whose countenance we steal.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Thou sayest well, and it holds well too; for the

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: fortune of us that are the moons men doth ebb and

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: flow like the sea, being governed, as the sea is,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: by the moon. As, for proof, now: a purse of gold

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: most resolutely snatched on Monday night and most

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: dissolutely spent on Tuesday morning; got with

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: swearing Lay by and spent with crying Bring in;

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: now in as low an ebb as the foot of the ladder

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: and by and by in as high a flow as the ridge of the gallows.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: By the Lord, thou sayest true, lad. And is not my

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: hostess of the tavern a most sweet wench?

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: As the honey of Hybla, my old lad of the castle. And

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: is not a buff jerkin a most sweet robe of durance?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: How now, how now, mad wag! what, in thy quips and

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: thy quiddities? what a plague have I to do with a

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: buff jerkin?

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Why, what a pox have I to do with my hostess of the tavern?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Well, thou hast called her to a reckoning many a

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: time and oft.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: No; Ill give thee thy due, thou hast paid all there.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Yea, and elsewhere, so far as my coin would stretch;

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: and where it would not, I have used my credit.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Yea, and so used it that were it not here apparent

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: that thou art heir apparent--But, I prithee, sweet

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: wag, shall there be gallows standing in England when

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: thou art king? and resolution thus fobbed as it is

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: with the rusty curb of old father antic the law? Do

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: not thou, when thou art king, hang a thief.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: No; thou shalt.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Shall I? O rare! By the Lord, Ill be a brave judge.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Thou judgest false already: I mean, thou shalt have

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: the hanging of the thieves and so become a rare hangman.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Well, Hal, well; and in some sort it jumps with my

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: humour as well as waiting in the court, I can tell

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: you.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: For obtaining of suits?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Yea, for obtaining of suits, whereof the hangman

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: hath no lean wardrobe. Sblood, I am as melancholy

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: as a gib cat or a lugged bear.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Or an old lion, or a lovers lute.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Yea, or the drone of a Lincolnshire bagpipe.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: What sayest thou to a hare, or the melancholy of

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Moor-ditch?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Thou hast the most unsavoury similes and art indeed

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: the most comparative, rascalliest, sweet young

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: prince. But, Hal, I prithee, trouble me no more

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: with vanity. I would to God thou and I knew where a

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: commodity of good names were to be bought. An old

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: lord of the council rated me the other day in the

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: street about you, sir, but I marked him not; and yet

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: he talked very wisely, but I regarded him not; and

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: yet he talked wisely, and in the street too.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Thou didst well; for wisdom cries out in the

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: streets, and no man regards it.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: O, thou hast damnable iteration and art indeed able

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: to corrupt a saint. Thou hast done much harm upon

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: me, Hal; God forgive thee for it! Before I knew

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: thee, Hal, I knew nothing; and now am I, if a man

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: should speak truly, little better than one of the

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: wicked. I must give over this life, and I will give

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: it over: by the Lord, and I do not, I am a villain:

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Ill be damned for never a kings son in

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Christendom.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Where shall we take a purse tomorrow, Jack?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Zounds, where thou wilt, lad; Ill make one; an I

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: do not, call me villain and baffle me.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: I see a good amendment of life in thee; from praying

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: to purse-taking.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Why, Hal, tis my vocation, Hal; tis no sin for a

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: man to labour in his vocation.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Enter POINS

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Poins! Now shall we know if Gadshill have set a

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: match. O, if men were to be saved by merit, what

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: hole in hell were hot enough for him? This is the

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: most omnipotent villain that ever cried Stand to

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: a true man.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Good morrow, Ned.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Good morrow, sweet Hal. What says Monsieur Remorse?

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: what says Sir John Sack and Sugar? Jack! how

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: agrees the devil and thee about thy soul, that thou

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: soldest him on Good-Friday last for a cup of Madeira

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: and a cold capons leg?

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Sir John stands to his word, the devil shall have

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: his bargain; for he was never yet a breaker of

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: proverbs: he will give the devil his due.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Then art thou damned for keeping thy word with the devil.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Else he had been damned for cozening the devil.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: But, my lads, my lads, to-morrow morning, by four

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: oclock, early at Gadshill! there are pilgrims going

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: to Canterbury with rich offerings, and traders

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: riding to London with fat purses: I have vizards

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: for you all; you have horses for yourselves:

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Gadshill lies to-night in Rochester: I have bespoke

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: supper to-morrow night in Eastcheap: we may do it

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: as secure as sleep. If you will go, I will stuff

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: your purses full of crowns; if you will not, tarry

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: at home and be hanged.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Hear ye, Yedward; if I tarry at home and go not,

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Ill hang you for going.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: You will, chops?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Hal, wilt thou make one?

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Who, I rob? I a thief? not I, by my faith.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Theres neither honesty, manhood, nor good

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: fellowship in thee, nor thou camest not of the blood

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: royal, if thou darest not stand for ten shillings.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Well then, once in my days Ill be a madcap.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Why, thats well said.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Well, come what will, Ill tarry at home.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: By the Lord, Ill be a traitor then, when thou art king.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: I care not.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Sir John, I prithee, leave the prince and me alone:

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: I will lay him down such reasons for this adventure

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: that he shall go.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Well, God give thee the spirit of persuasion and him

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: the ears of profiting, that what thou speakest may

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: move and what he hears may be believed, that the

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: true prince may, for recreation sake, prove a false

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: thief; for the poor abuses of the time want

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: countenance. Farewell: you shall find me in Eastcheap.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Farewell, thou latter spring! farewell, All-hallown summer!

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Exit Falstaff

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Now, my good sweet honey lord, ride with us

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: to-morrow: I have a jest to execute that I cannot

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: manage alone. Falstaff, Bardolph, Peto and Gadshill

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: shall rob those men that we have already waylaid:

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: yourself and I will not be there; and when they

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: have the booty, if you and I do not rob them, cut

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: this head off from my shoulders.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: How shall we part with them in setting forth?

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Why, we will set forth before or after them, and

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: appoint them a place of meeting, wherein it is at

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: our pleasure to fail, and then will they adventure

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: upon the exploit themselves; which they shall have

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: no sooner achieved, but well set upon them.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Yea, but tis like that they will know us by our

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: horses, by our habits and by every other

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: appointment, to be ourselves.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Tut! our horses they shall not see: Ill tie them

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: in the wood; our vizards we will change after we

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: leave them: and, sirrah, I have cases of buckram

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: for the nonce, to immask our noted outward garments.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Yea, but I doubt they will be too hard for us.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Well, for two of them, I know them to be as

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: true-bred cowards as ever turned back; and for the

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: third, if he fight longer than he sees reason, Ill

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: forswear arms. The virtue of this jest will be, the

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: incomprehensible lies that this same fat rogue will

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: tell us when we meet at supper: how thirty, at

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: least, he fought with; what wards, what blows, what

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: extremities he endured; and in the reproof of this

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: lies the jest.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Well, Ill go with thee: provide us all things

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: necessary and meet me to-morrow night in Eastcheap;

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: there Ill sup. Farewell.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Farewell, my lord.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Exit Poins

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: I know you all, and will awhile uphold

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: The unyoked humour of your idleness:

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Yet herein will I imitate the sun,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Who doth permit the base contagious clouds

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: To smother up his beauty from the world,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: That, when he please again to be himself,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Being wanted, he may be more wonderd at,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: By breaking through the foul and ugly mists

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Of vapours that did seem to strangle him.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: If all the year were playing holidays,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: To sport would be as tedious as to work;

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: But when they seldom come, they wishd for come,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: And nothing pleaseth but rare accidents.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: So, when this loose behavior I throw off

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: And pay the debt I never promised,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: By how much better than my word I am,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: By so much shall I falsify mens hopes;

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: And like bright metal on a sullen ground,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: My reformation, glittering oer my fault,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Shall show more goodly and attract more eyes

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Than that which hath no foil to set it off.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Ill so offend, to make offence a skill;

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Redeeming time when men think least I will.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Exit

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: SCENE III. London. The palace.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Enter the KING, NORTHUMBERLAND, WORCESTER, HOTSPUR, SIR WALTER BLUNT, with others

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: My blood hath been too cold and temperate,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Unapt to stir at these indignities,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And you have found me; for accordingly

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: You tread upon my patience: but be sure

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: I will from henceforth rather be myself,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Mighty and to be feard, than my condition;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Which hath been smooth as oil, soft as young down,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And therefore lost that title of respect

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Which the proud soul neer pays but to the proud.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Our house, my sovereign liege, little deserves

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: The scourge of greatness to be used on it;

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And that same greatness too which our own hands

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Have holp to make so portly.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: My lord.--

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Worcester, get thee gone; for I do see

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Danger and disobedience in thine eye:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: O, sir, your presence is too bold and peremptory,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: And majesty might never yet endure

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: The moody frontier of a servant brow.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: You have good leave to leave us: when we need

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Your use and counsel, we shall send for you.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Exit Worcester

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: You were about to speak.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: To North

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Yea, my good lord.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Those prisoners in your highness name demanded,

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Which Harry Percy here at Holmedon took,

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Were, as he says, not with such strength denied

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: As is deliverd to your majesty:

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Either envy, therefore, or misprison

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Is guilty of this fault and not my son.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: My liege, I did deny no prisoners.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But I remember, when the fight was done,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: When I was dry with rage and extreme toil,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Breathless and faint, leaning upon my sword,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Came there a certain lord, neat, and trimly dressd,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Fresh as a bridegroom; and his chin new reapd

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Showd like a stubble-land at harvest-home;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He was perfumed like a milliner;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And twixt his finger and his thumb he held

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: A pouncet-box, which ever and anon

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He gave his nose and tookt away again;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Who therewith angry, when it next came there,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Took it in snuff; and still he smiled and talkd,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And as the soldiers bore dead bodies by,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He calld them untaught knaves, unmannerly,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To bring a slovenly unhandsome corse

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Betwixt the wind and his nobility.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: With many holiday and lady terms

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He questiond me; amongst the rest, demanded

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: My prisoners in your majestys behalf.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: I then, all smarting with my wounds being cold,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To be so pesterd with a popinjay,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Out of my grief and my impatience,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Answerd neglectingly I know not what,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He should or he should not; for he made me mad

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To see him shine so brisk and smell so sweet

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And talk so like a waiting-gentlewoman

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Of guns and drums and wounds,--God save the mark!--

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And telling me the sovereignst thing on earth

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Was parmaceti for an inward bruise;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And that it was great pity, so it was,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: This villanous salt-petre should be diggd

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Out of the bowels of the harmless earth,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Which many a good tall fellow had destroyd

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: So cowardly; and but for these vile guns,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He would himself have been a soldier.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: This bald unjointed chat of his, my lord,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: I answerd indirectly, as I said;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And I beseech you, let not his report

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Come current for an accusation

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Betwixt my love and your high majesty.

docs.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
docs.text_entry: The circumstance considerd, good my lord,

docs.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
docs.text_entry: Whateer Lord Harry Percy then had said

docs.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
docs.text_entry: To such a person and in such a place,

docs.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
docs.text_entry: At such a time, with all the rest retold,

docs.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
docs.text_entry: May reasonably die and never rise

docs.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
docs.text_entry: To do him wrong or any way impeach

docs.speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
docs.text_entry: What then he said, so he unsay it now.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Why, yet he doth deny his prisoners,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: But with proviso and exception,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: That we at our own charge shall ransom straight

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: His brother-in-law, the foolish Mortimer;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Who, on my soul, hath wilfully betrayd

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: The lives of those that he did lead to fight

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Against that great magician, damnd Glendower,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Whose daughter, as we hear, the Earl of March

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Hath lately married. Shall our coffers, then,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Be emptied to redeem a traitor home?

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Shall we but treason? and indent with fears,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: When they have lost and forfeited themselves?

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: No, on the barren mountains let him starve;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: For I shall never hold that man my friend

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Whose tongue shall ask me for one penny cost

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: To ransom home revolted Mortimer.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Revolted Mortimer!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He never did fall off, my sovereign liege,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But by the chance of war; to prove that true

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Needs no more but one tongue for all those wounds,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Those mouthed wounds, which valiantly he took

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: When on the gentle Severns sedgy bank,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: In single opposition, hand to hand,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He did confound the best part of an hour

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: In changing hardiment with great Glendower:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Three times they breathed and three times did

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: they drink,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Upon agreement, of swift Severns flood;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Who then, affrighted with their bloody looks,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Ran fearfully among the trembling reeds,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And hid his crisp head in the hollow bank,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Bloodstained with these valiant combatants.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Never did base and rotten policy

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Colour her working with such deadly wounds;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Nor could the noble Mortimer

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Receive so many, and all willingly:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Then let not him be slanderd with revolt.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Thou dost belie him, Percy, thou dost belie him;

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: He never did encounter with Glendower:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: I tell thee,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: He durst as well have met the devil alone

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: As Owen Glendower for an enemy.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Art thou not ashamed? But, sirrah, henceforth

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Let me not hear you speak of Mortimer:

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Send me your prisoners with the speediest means,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Or you shall hear in such a kind from me

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: As will displease you. My Lord Northumberland,

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: We licence your departure with your son.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Send us your prisoners, or you will hear of it.

docs.speaker: KING HENRY IV
docs.text_entry: Exeunt King Henry, Blunt, and train

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: An if the devil come and roar for them,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: I will not send them: I will after straight

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And tell him so; for I will ease my heart,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Albeit I make a hazard of my head.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: What, drunk with choler? stay and pause awhile:

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Here comes your uncle.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Re-enter WORCESTER

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Speak of Mortimer!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Zounds, I will speak of him; and let my soul

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Want mercy, if I do not join with him:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Yea, on his part Ill empty all these veins,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And shed my dear blood drop by drop in the dust,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But I will lift the down-trod Mortimer

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: As high in the air as this unthankful king,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: As this ingrate and cankerd Bolingbroke.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Brother, the king hath made your nephew mad.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Who struck this heat up after I was gone?

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He will, forsooth, have all my prisoners;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And when I urged the ransom once again

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Of my wifes brother, then his cheek lookd pale,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And on my face he turnd an eye of death,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Trembling even at the name of Mortimer.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: I cannot blame him: was not he proclaimd

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: By Richard that dead is the next of blood?

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: He was; I heard the proclamation:

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: And then it was when the unhappy king,

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: --Whose wrongs in us God pardon!--did set forth

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Upon his Irish expedition;

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: From whence he intercepted did return

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: To be deposed and shortly murdered.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And for whose death we in the worlds wide mouth

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Live scandalized and foully spoken of.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But soft, I pray you; did King Richard then

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Proclaim my brother Edmund Mortimer

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Heir to the crown?

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: He did; myself did hear it.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Nay, then I cannot blame his cousin king,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: That wished him on the barren mountains starve.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But shall it be that you, that set the crown

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Upon the head of this forgetful man

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And for his sake wear the detested blot

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Of murderous subornation, shall it be,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: That you a world of curses undergo,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Being the agents, or base second means,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: The cords, the ladder, or the hangman rather?

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: O, pardon me that I descend so low,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To show the line and the predicament

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Wherein you range under this subtle king;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Shall it for shame be spoken in these days,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Or fill up chronicles in time to come,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: That men of your nobility and power

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Did gage them both in an unjust behalf,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: As both of you--God pardon it!--have done,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To put down Richard, that sweet lovely rose,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: An plant this thorn, this canker, Bolingbroke?

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And shall it in more shame be further spoken,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: That you are foold, discarded and shook off

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: By him for whom these shames ye underwent?

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: No; yet time serves wherein you may redeem

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Your banishd honours and restore yourselves

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Into the good thoughts of the world again,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Revenge the jeering and disdaind contempt

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Of this proud king, who studies day and night

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To answer all the debt he owes to you

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Even with the bloody payment of your deaths:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Therefore, I say--

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Peace, cousin, say no more:

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And now I will unclasp a secret book,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And to your quick-conceiving discontents

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Ill read you matter deep and dangerous,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: As full of peril and adventurous spirit

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: As to oer-walk a current roaring loud

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: On the unsteadfast footing of a spear.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: If he fall in, good night! or sink or swim:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Send danger from the east unto the west,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: So honour cross it from the north to south,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And let them grapple: O, the blood more stirs

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To rouse a lion than to start a hare!

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Imagination of some great exploit

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Drives him beyond the bounds of patience.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: By heaven, methinks it were an easy leap,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To pluck bright honour from the pale-faced moon,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Or dive into the bottom of the deep,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Where fathom-line could never touch the ground,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And pluck up drowned honour by the locks;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: So he that doth redeem her thence might wear

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Without corrival, all her dignities:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But out upon this half-faced fellowship!

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: He apprehends a world of figures here,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: But not the form of what he should attend.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Good cousin, give me audience for a while.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: I cry you mercy.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Those same noble Scots

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: That are your prisoners,--

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Ill keep them all;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: By God, he shall not have a Scot of them;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: No, if a Scot would save his soul, he shall not:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Ill keep them, by this hand.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: You start away

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And lend no ear unto my purposes.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Those prisoners you shall keep.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Nay, I will; thats flat:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He said he would not ransom Mortimer;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Forbad my tongue to speak of Mortimer;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But I will find him when he lies asleep,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And in his ear Ill holla Mortimer!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Nay,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Ill have a starling shall be taught to speak

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Nothing but Mortimer, and give it him

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To keep his anger still in motion.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Hear you, cousin; a word.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: All studies here I solemnly defy,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Save how to gall and pinch this Bolingbroke:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And that same sword-and-buckler Prince of Wales,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But that I think his father loves him not

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And would be glad he met with some mischance,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: I would have him poisond with a pot of ale.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Farewell, kinsman: Ill talk to you

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: When you are better temperd to attend.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Why, what a wasp-stung and impatient fool

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Art thou to break into this womans mood,

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Tying thine ear to no tongue but thine own!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Why, look you, I am whippd and scourged with rods,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Nettled and stung with pismires, when I hear

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Of this vile politician, Bolingbroke.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: In Richards time,--what do you call the place?--

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: A plague upon it, it is in Gloucestershire;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Twas where the madcap duke his uncle kept,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: His uncle York; where I first bowd my knee

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Unto this king of smiles, this Bolingbroke,--

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Sblood!--

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: When you and he came back from Ravenspurgh.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: At Berkley castle.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: You say true:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Why, what a candy deal of courtesy

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: This fawning greyhound then did proffer me!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Look,when his infant fortune came to age,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And gentle Harry Percy, and kind cousin;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: O, the devil take such cozeners! God forgive me!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Good uncle, tell your tale; I have done.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Nay, if you have not, to it again;

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: We will stay your leisure.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: I have done, i faith.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Then once more to your Scottish prisoners.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Deliver them up without their ransom straight,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And make the Douglas son your only mean

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: For powers in Scotland; which, for divers reasons

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Which I shall send you written, be assured,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Will easily be granted. You, my lord,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: To Northumberland

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Your son in Scotland being thus employd,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Shall secretly into the bosom creep

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Of that same noble prelate, well beloved,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: The archbishop.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Of York, is it not?

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: True; who bears hard

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: His brothers death at Bristol, the Lord Scroop.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: I speak not this in estimation,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: As what I think might be, but what I know

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Is ruminated, plotted and set down,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And only stays but to behold the face

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Of that occasion that shall bring it on.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: I smell it: upon my life, it will do well.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Before the game is afoot, thou still letst slip.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Why, it cannot choose but be a noble plot;

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: And then the power of Scotland and of York,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: To join with Mortimer, ha?

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And so they shall.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: In faith, it is exceedingly well aimd.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And tis no little reason bids us speed,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: To save our heads by raising of a head;

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: For, bear ourselves as even as we can,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: The king will always think him in our debt,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And think we think ourselves unsatisfied,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Till he hath found a time to pay us home:

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: And see already how he doth begin

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: To make us strangers to his looks of love.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: He does, he does: well be revenged on him.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Cousin, farewell: no further go in this

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Than I by letters shall direct your course.

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: When time is ripe, which will be suddenly,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Ill steal to Glendower and Lord Mortimer;

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Where you and Douglas and our powers at once,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: As I will fashion it, shall happily meet,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: To bear our fortunes in our own strong arms,

docs.speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
docs.text_entry: Which now we hold at much uncertainty.

docs.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
docs.text_entry: Farewell, good brother: we shall thrive, I trust.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Uncle, Adieu: O, let the hours be short

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Till fields and blows and groans applaud our sport!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Exeunt

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: ACT II

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: SCENE I. Rochester. An inn yard.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Enter a Carrier with a lantern in his hand

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: Heigh-ho! an it be not four by the day, Ill be

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: hanged: Charles wain is over the new chimney, and

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: yet our horse not packed. What, ostler!

docs.speaker: Ostler
docs.text_entry: [Within]   Anon, anon.

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: I prithee, Tom, beat Cuts saddle, put a few flocks

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: in the point; poor jade, is wrung in the withers out

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: of all cess.

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: Enter another Carrier

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: Peas and beans are as dank here as a dog, and that

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: is the next way to give poor jades the bots: this

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: house is turned upside down since Robin Ostler died.

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: Poor fellow, never joyed since the price of oats

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: rose; it was the death of him.

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: I think this be the most villanous house in all

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: London road for fleas: I am stung like a tench.

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: Like a tench! by the mass, there is neer a king

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: christen could be better bit than I have been since

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: the first cock.

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: Why, they will allow us neer a jordan, and then we

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: leak in your chimney; and your chamber-lie breeds

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: fleas like a loach.

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: What, ostler! come away and be hanged!

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: I have a gammon of bacon and two razors of ginger,

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: to be delivered as far as Charing-cross.

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: Gods body! the turkeys in my pannier are quite

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: starved. What, ostler! A plague on thee! hast thou

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: never an eye in thy head? canst not hear? An

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: twere not as good deed as drink, to break the pate

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: on thee, I am a very villain. Come, and be hanged!

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: hast thou no faith in thee?

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: Enter GADSHILL

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Good morrow, carriers. Whats oclock?

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: I think it be two oclock.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: I pray thee lend me thy lantern, to see my gelding

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: in the stable.

docs.speaker: First Carrier
docs.text_entry: Nay, by God, soft; I know a trick worth two of that, i faith.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: I pray thee, lend me thine.

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: Ay, when? canst tell? Lend me thy lantern, quoth

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: he? marry, Ill see thee hanged first.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Sirrah carrier, what time do you mean to come to London?

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: Time enough to go to bed with a candle, I warrant

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: thee. Come, neighbour Mugs, well call up the

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: gentleman: they will along with company, for they

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: have great charge.

docs.speaker: Second Carrier
docs.text_entry: Exeunt carriers

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: What, ho! chamberlain!

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: [Within]  At hand, quoth pick-purse.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Thats even as fair as--at hand, quoth the

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: chamberlain; for thou variest no more from picking

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: of purses than giving direction doth from labouring;

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: thou layest the plot how.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Enter Chamberlain

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: Good morrow, Master Gadshill. It holds current that

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: I told you yesternight: theres a franklin in the

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: wild of Kent hath brought three hundred marks with

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: him in gold: I heard him tell it to one of his

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: company last night at supper; a kind of auditor; one

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: that hath abundance of charge too, God knows what.

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: They are up already, and call for eggs and butter;

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: they will away presently.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Sirrah, if they meet not with Saint Nicholas

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: clerks, Ill give thee this neck.

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: No, Ill none of it: I pray thee keep that for the

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: hangman; for I know thou worshippest St. Nicholas

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: as truly as a man of falsehood may.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: What talkest thou to me of the hangman? if I hang,

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Ill make a fat pair of gallows; for if I hang, old

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Sir John hangs with me, and thou knowest he is no

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: starveling. Tut! there are other Trojans that thou

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: dreamest not of, the which for sport sake are

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: content to do the profession some grace; that would,

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: if matters should be looked into, for their own

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: credit sake, make all whole. I am joined with no

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: foot-land rakers, no long-staff sixpenny strikers,

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: none of these mad mustachio purple-hued malt-worms;

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: but with nobility and tranquillity, burgomasters and

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: great oneyers, such as can hold in, such as will

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: strike sooner than speak, and speak sooner than

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: drink, and drink sooner than pray: and yet, zounds,

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: I lie; for they pray continually to their saint, the

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: commonwealth; or rather, not pray to her, but prey

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: on her, for they ride up and down on her and make

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: her their boots.

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: What, the commonwealth their boots? will she hold

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: out water in foul way?

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: She will, she will; justice hath liquored her. We

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: steal as in a castle, cocksure; we have the receipt

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: of fern-seed, we walk invisible.

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: Nay, by my faith, I think you are more beholding to

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: the night than to fern-seed for your walking invisible.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Give me thy hand: thou shalt have a share in our

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: purchase, as I am a true man.

docs.speaker: Chamberlain
docs.text_entry: Nay, rather let me have it, as you are a false thief.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Go to; homo is a common name to all men. Bid the

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: ostler bring my gelding out of the stable. Farewell,

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: you muddy knave.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Exeunt

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: SCENE II. The highway, near Gadshill.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Come, shelter, shelter: I have removed Falstaffs

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: horse, and he frets like a gummed velvet.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Stand close.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Enter FALSTAFF

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Poins! Poins, and be hanged! Poins!

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Peace, ye fat-kidneyed rascal! what a brawling dost

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: thou keep!

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Wheres Poins, Hal?

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: He is walked up to the top of the hill: Ill go seek him.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: I am accursed to rob in that thiefs company: the

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: rascal hath removed my horse, and tied him I know

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: not where. If I travel but four foot by the squier

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: further afoot, I shall break my wind. Well, I doubt

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: not but to die a fair death for all this, if I

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: scape hanging for killing that rogue. I have

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: forsworn his company hourly any time this two and

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: twenty years, and yet I am bewitched with the

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: rogues company. If the rascal hath not given me

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: medicines to make me love him, Ill be hanged; it

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: could not be else: I have drunk medicines. Poins!

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Hal! a plague upon you both! Bardolph! Peto!

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Ill starve ere Ill rob a foot further. An twere

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: not as good a deed as drink, to turn true man and to

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: leave these rogues, I am the veriest varlet that

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: ever chewed with a tooth. Eight yards of uneven

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: ground is threescore and ten miles afoot with me;

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: and the stony-hearted villains know it well enough:

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: a plague upon it when thieves cannot be true one to another!

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: They whistle

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Whew! A plague upon you all! Give me my horse, you

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: rogues; give me my horse, and be hanged!

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Peace, ye fat-guts! lie down; lay thine ear close

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: to the ground and list if thou canst hear the tread

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: of travellers.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Have you any levers to lift me up again, being down?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Sblood, Ill not bear mine own flesh so far afoot

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: again for all the coin in thy fathers exchequer.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: What a plague mean ye to colt me thus?

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Thou liest; thou art not colted, thou art uncolted.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: I prithee, good Prince Hal, help me to my horse,

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: good kings son.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Out, ye rogue! shall I be your ostler?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Go, hang thyself in thine own heir-apparent

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: garters! If I be taen, Ill peach for this. An I

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: have not ballads made on you all and sung to filthy

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: tunes, let a cup of sack be my poison: when a jest

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: is so forward, and afoot too! I hate it.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Enter GADSHILL, BARDOLPH and PETO

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Stand.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: So I do, against my will.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: O, tis our setter: I know his voice. Bardolph,

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: what news?

docs.speaker: BARDOLPH
docs.text_entry: Case ye, case ye; on with your vizards: there s

docs.speaker: BARDOLPH
docs.text_entry: money of the kings coming down the hill; tis going

docs.speaker: BARDOLPH
docs.text_entry: to the kings exchequer.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: You lie, ye rogue; tis going to the kings tavern.

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Theres enough to make us all.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: To be hanged.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Sirs, you four shall front them in the narrow lane;

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Ned Poins and I will walk lower: if they scape

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: from your encounter, then they light on us.

docs.speaker: PETO
docs.text_entry: How many be there of them?

docs.speaker: GADSHILL
docs.text_entry: Some eight or ten.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Zounds, will they not rob us?

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: What, a coward, Sir John Paunch?

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Indeed, I am not John of Gaunt, your grandfather;

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: but yet no coward, Hal.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Well, we leave that to the proof.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Sirrah Jack, thy horse stands behind the hedge:

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: when thou needest him, there thou shalt find him.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Farewell, and stand fast.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Now cannot I strike him, if I should be hanged.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Ned, where are our disguises?

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Here, hard by: stand close.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Exeunt PRINCE HENRY and POINS

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Now, my masters, happy man be his dole, say I:

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: every man to his business.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Enter the Travellers

docs.speaker: First Traveller
docs.text_entry: Come, neighbour: the boy shall lead our horses down

docs.speaker: First Traveller
docs.text_entry: the hill; well walk afoot awhile, and ease our legs.

docs.speaker: Thieves
docs.text_entry: Stand!

docs.speaker: Travellers
docs.text_entry: Jesus bless us!

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Strike; down with them; cut the villains throats:

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: ah! whoreson caterpillars! bacon-fed knaves! they

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: hate us youth: down with them: fleece them.

docs.speaker: Travellers
docs.text_entry: O, we are undone, both we and ours for ever!

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Hang ye, gorbellied knaves, are ye undone? No, ye

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: fat chuffs: I would your store were here! On,

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: bacons, on! What, ye knaves! young men must live.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: You are Grand-jurors, are ye? well jure ye, faith.

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Here they rob them and bind them. Exeunt

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Re-enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: The thieves have bound the true men. Now could thou

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: and I rob the thieves and go merrily to London, it

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: would be argument for a week, laughter for a month

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: and a good jest for ever.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Stand close; I hear them coming.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Enter the Thieves again

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: Come, my masters, let us share, and then to  horse

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: before day. An the Prince and Poins be not two

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: arrant cowards, theres no equity stirring: theres

docs.speaker: FALSTAFF
docs.text_entry: no more valour in that Poins than in a wild-duck.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Your money!

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Villains!

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: As they are sharing, the Prince and Poins set upon  them; they all run away; and Falstaff, after a blow or two, runs away too, leaving the booty behind them

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Got with much ease. Now merrily to horse:

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: The thieves are all scatterd and possessd with fear

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: So strongly that they dare not meet each other;

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Each takes his fellow for an officer.

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Away, good Ned. Falstaff sweats to death,

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: And lards the lean earth as he walks along:

docs.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
docs.text_entry: Were t not for laughing, I should pity him.

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: How the rogue roard!

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Exeunt

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: SCENE III. Warkworth castle

docs.speaker: POINS
docs.text_entry: Enter HOTSPUR, solus, reading a letter

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: But for mine own part, my lord, I could be well

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: contented to be there, in respect of the love I bear

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: your house. He could be contented: why is he not,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: then? In respect of the love he bears our house:

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: he shows in this, he loves his own barn better than

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: he loves our house. Let me see some more. The

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: purpose you undertake is dangerous;--why, thats

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: certain: tis dangerous to take a cold, to sleep, to

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: drink; but I tell you, my lord fool, out of this

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: nettle, danger, we pluck this flower, safety. The

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: purpose you undertake is dangerous; the friends you

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: have named uncertain; the time itself unsorted; and

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: your whole plot too light for the counterpoise of so

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: great an opposition. Say you so, say you so? I say

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: unto you again, you are a shallow cowardly hind, and

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: you lie.  What a lack-brain is this! By the Lord,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: our plot is a good plot as ever was laid; our

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: friends true and constant: a good plot, good

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: friends, and full of expectation; an excellent plot,

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: very good friends. What a frosty-spirited rogue is

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: this! Why, my lord of York commends the plot and the

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: general course of action. Zounds, an I were now by

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: this rascal, I could brain him with his ladys fan.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Is there not my father, my uncle and myself? lord

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Edmund Mortimer, My lord of York and Owen Glendower?

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: is there not besides the Douglas? have I not all

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: their letters to meet me in arms by the ninth of the

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: next month? and are they not some of them set

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: forward already? What a pagan rascal is this! an

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: infidel! Ha! you shall see now in very sincerity

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: of fear and cold heart, will he to the king and lay

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: open all our proceedings. O, I could divide myself

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: and go to buffets, for moving such a dish of

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: skim milk with so honourable an action! Hang him!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: let him tell the king: we are prepared. I will set

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: forward to-night.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Enter LADY PERCY

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: How now, Kate! I must leave you within these two hours.

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: O, my good lord, why are you thus alone?

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: For what offence have I this fortnight been

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: A banishd woman from my Harrys bed?

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Tell me, sweet lord, what ist that takes from thee

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Thy stomach, pleasure and thy golden sleep?

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: And start so often when thou sitst alone?

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheeks;

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: And given my treasures and my rights of thee

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: To thick-eyed musing and cursed melancholy?

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: In thy faint slumbers I by thee have watchd,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: And heard thee murmur tales of iron wars;

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Speak terms of manage to thy bounding steed;

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Cry Courage! to the field! And thou hast talkd

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Of sallies and retires, of trenches, tents,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Of palisadoes, frontiers, parapets,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Of basilisks, of cannon, culverin,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Of prisoners ransom and of soldiers slain,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: And all the currents of a heady fight.

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Thy spirit within thee hath been so at war

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: And thus hath so bestirrd thee in thy sleep,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: That beads of sweat have stood upon thy brow

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Like bubbles in a late-disturbed stream;

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: And in thy face strange motions have appeard,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Such as we see when men restrain their breath

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: On some great sudden hest. O, what portents are these?

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Some heavy business hath my lord in hand,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: And I must know it, else he loves me not.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: What, ho!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Enter Servant

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Is Gilliams with the packet gone?

docs.speaker: Servant
docs.text_entry: He is, my lord, an hour ago.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Hath Butler brought those horses from the sheriff?

docs.speaker: Servant
docs.text_entry: One horse, my lord, he brought even now.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: What horse? a roan, a crop-ear, is it not?

docs.speaker: Servant
docs.text_entry: It is, my lord.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: That roan shall by my throne.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Well, I will back him straight: O esperance!

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Bid Butler lead him forth into the park.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Exit Servant

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: But hear you, my lord.

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: What sayst thou, my lady?

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: What is it carries you away?

docs.speaker: HOTSPUR
docs.text_entry: Why, my horse, my love, my horse.

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Out, you mad-headed ape!

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: A weasel hath not such a deal of spleen

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: As you are tossd with. In faith,

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: Ill know your business, Harry, that I will.

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: I fear my brother Mortimer doth stir

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
docs.text_entry: About his title, and hath sent for you

docs.speaker: LADY PERCY
